en.value: What are you doing at the weekend?
Making plans and talking about future activities - Verb patterns, Future with "will" and "going to"
Do you have any plans?
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
Friday, at last! Do you have any [k]plans[/k] for the weekend?
I [k]have a barbecue[/k] on Saturday and on Sunday I am going to [k]spend some time[/k] with the family. We might go to the pub for a Sunday roast. Quiet weekend, really. How about you?
I’m going away for the weekend. I have [k]tickets[/k] for a festival in Paris.
So jealous! I love festivals but I always forget to buy tickets until it’s too late. When are you going?
I’m travelling tomorrow. Tonight I’m [k]going to a party[/k]. Do you want to come? It’ll be cool!
I don’t know, I finish work quite late today.
I’m starting to think you don’t like spending time with me! Haha. No, I’m joking. I still like you.
Tamsin
Tom

We've just listened to a dialogue between two friends who are talking about their weekend plans. Now we'll learn some useful expressions to ask and talk about ours and others' plans, so you can tell your friends all the fun things you're up to and ask them to join you! Here's an example of a conversation you will be able to have after finishing this unit:
Do you have any plans?
I have tickets for a comedy show this weekend.
That's cool! We're going to have a barbecue if the weather is nice.
Here's a tip!
to plan to do something
I was planning to visit my friends in Liverpool.
Memorise the word(s).
[k]Do[/k] [k]you[/k] [k]have[/k] [k]any[/k] [k]plans?[/k]
Select the words in the correct order.
to spend time
Why don't we spend time with the family?
Complete the sentence with the correct verb form: I don't want to spend time...
baking a cake this weekend.
bake a cake this weekend.
with a cake this weekend.
I will spend some time [k]with[/k] my family on Sunday.
cooking
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
to leave time for
Let's leave time for watching the football.
Match the beginning and the end of the phrase.
Let’s leave time
Let's spend some time
for grabbing some food.
at home this weekend.
to have a barbecue
We're going to have a barbecue if the weather is nice.
What are Tom's plans for the weekend?
to spend some time with family and have a barbecue on Saturday
to spend some time in the pub and leave time for a Sunday roast
to spend some time with family and have a barbecue at the pub
to go away for the weekend
Are you going away for the weekend?
to go to a party
He's going to a party on Saturday.
Match the beginning with the end of the sentence.
Ben is packing his backpack, he is going
Ben is buying some drinks, he is going to
away for the weekend.
a party.
to have tickets for something
I have tickets for a comedy show this weekend.
I [k]have tickets for[/k] a festival next weekend.
Fill in the gap using the audio.
What are Tamsin's plans for the weekend?
She is going away for the weekend and has tickets for a festival.
She has a barbecue and is going away for the weekend.
She is spending time with her family and going to a party.
Do you [k]have any plans[/k]?
We need to [k]leave time[/k] [k]for[/k] dinner before we go out.
spend time
with
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
I don't want to [k]spend time[/k] [k]cooking[/k].
have time
with
Complete the sentence: He spends lots of time…
doing his hair.
do his hair.
done his hair.
I am not going to the party, I finish [k]working[/k] quite late today.
Complete the sentence using the audio. Remember that we follow "to finish" with a verb ending in -ing.
Zoe has [k]tickets[/k] for the concert.
We need one of these to get into a concert or festival.
Fill in the gap using the hint.
We're going to have a [k]barbecue|barbeque[/k] if the weather is nice.
Lola is going [k]away[/k] [k]for[/k] the weekend.
with
in
Let's have a recap of the useful sentences we have learned. Can you ask or talk about your plans or your friends' plans? Give it a go in the next exercise!
Do you have any plans?
to plan to do something
to spend time
to leave time for
to have a barbecue
to go away for the weekend
to go to a party
to have tickets for something
Start a conversation about your weekend plans! Using the phrases you've just learned, tell the busuu community what you're going to do on Saturday and Sunday.
This weekend, I'm going to visit ... / I'm planning to go ... / I think I'll ...
Grammar: Verb combinations

We already know that sometimes we can use two verbs next to each other, and we've mostly seen one structure for doing this: verb + verb in ing-form (e.g. "I like singing."). Now we're going to learn another structure. Have a look at the examples below.
I don't want to spend too much time cooking.
Ah! I forgot to tell you!
It's starting to rain!
True or false?
Who wants to go camping this summer?
This sentence contains two verbs.
We [k]like[/k] to go on holiday in the summer.
liking
She remembered to buy a card on the way to the party.
As you may have noticed, the structure that we're practicing in this unit is verb + "to" + verb (or verb + infinitive).
We planned to go for dinner tonight..
Did you decide to stay at home?
Oh no. I forgot to buy milk.
Select the three words that form the verb combination.
Did you [h]remember[/h] [h]to[/h] [h]call[/h] your sister?
He's [h]starting[/h] [h]to[/h] [h]exercise[/h] more often.

Some verbs take "to" + verb and some take that verb in "-ing" form; some take either! We'll cover the rules in more detail in a few lessons. Here are some verbs which can take the "verb + to + verb" structure.
to want to do something
to mean to do something
to be supposed to do something
to decide to do something
to plan to do something
to start to do something
to begin to do something
to continue to do something
to forget to do something
to remember to do something
to try to do something
When do you want [k]to go[/k] for lunch?
going
[k]It[/k] [k]started[/k] [k]to[/k] [k]rain[/k] [k]when[/k] [k]we arrived at the park.[/k]
We decided [k]to stay in[/k] last night.
staying in
[k]I[/k] [k]was[/k] [k]supposed[/k] [k]to[/k] [k]tell you[/k] [k]about the party on Saturday.[/k]
Did you remember [k]to take out[/k] the trash?
He didn't [k]mean[/k] to [k]upset[/k] you.
means
upsetting
We forgot [k]to buy[/k] soap!
[k]I[/k] [k]want[/k] [k]to[/k] [k]go and see[/k] [k]that new film[/k] [k]at the cinema.[/k]
I was [k]trying to find[/k] you! Where were you?
to try (past continuous) + to find
You [k]weren't[/k] supposed [k]to know[/k] about the surprise!
knowning
wasn't
They've [k]decided to move[/k] out of London.
It's [k]beginning[/k] [k]to get[/k] a bit colder.
begin
getting
I'm supposed [k]to go for lunch[/k] with Charlotte.
[k]We[/k] [k]planned[/k] [k]to[/k] [k]go[/k] [k]travelling[/k] [k]this[/k] [k]summer.[/k]
I [k]forgot[/k] to [k]pack[/k] my sun glasses!
forgetting
packing
They [k]continued to drive|continued driving[/k] to work when they moved house.
to continue (past simple) + to drive
Grammar: Future
Let's talk about future plans! We're going to learn two slightly different ways to form the future tense using "will" and "to be + going to". Have a look at some examples below.
We are going to be late.
I'm busy now, I'll call you later.
I think she will get the job.
Grammar: Future plans (will / going to)
Select the future form you find in this sentence: "I am going to visit my friends in Cambridge."
be + going to
will
to be
Which future form do we use in this sentence?: I'm busy now, but I'll call you later.
will
be + going to
to be

The first structure for forming the future tense is "will" + verb. Both "will" and the verb in the sentence do not change; the verb is always in its base form. However, we often shorten "will" to "'ll" and attach it to the end of personal pronouns like "I, you, he, she, it, we and they". Here are some examples.
We don't know what we're doing later but I'll text you.
I think she'll love the present.
The waiter will have your table ready in a couple of minutes.
The future with "will"
Complete: I think she'll ... the present.
love
loves
loving
She'll [k]buy[/k] tickets for the concert next time.
buys
Choose the correct contraction.
I will
he will
they will
I'll
he'll
they'll
Question: Will Martha come with us to the party?
With question word: When will you come with me to a festival?
Negative: She won't need a lift to the party.

The structure for forming a question with "will" is will + (person/subject) + verb. If we use a question word, it goes to the beginning of the sentence. For negatives, it's "will" + "not" + verb. We often shorten "will" + "not" to "won't". In both negative sentences and questions, remember, the verb still does not change its form.
Questions and negatives with "will"
Select the shortened negative form of "will".
won't
'll
want
[k]When[/k] [k]will[/k] [k]you[/k] [k]arrive[/k] [k]at[/k] [k]the[/k] [k]airport?[/k]
What's the question form of the following statement?: Ava will visit us soon.
Will Ava visit us soon?
Does Ava visit us soon?
Are you visiting us soon?
When do we use "will"?
Let's see when we use "will" to talk about the future:
when we decide to do something now (spontaneous decision): I'll pay for the drinks.
when we make an offer, a promise or a threat: I'll stay later next time.
when we think or believe something about the future: It's a fancy hotel. I think our room will be nice.
Complete: I promise we ... with you to the concert.
'll go
'll
ll go
Match each sentence with its use.
Next time, I'll go with you.
It's cold! I'll take my jacket.
I think they'll be on time.
making a promise
making a spontaneous decision
making a future prediction
[k]Will[/k] [k]you[/k] [k]cook[/k] [k]for[/k] [k]us[/k] [k]?[/k]
Type the negative form of "will".
She [k]won't|will not[/k] get home until 8 pm tonight.

The other structure that we'll learn is to be + "going to" + verb. In this structure, "to be" is in the present tense and it changes depending on the person who's going to perform the action. The main verb does not change. Here are some examples.
Future with "be + going to"
We're going to buy tickets for the concert.
He's not going to come to Dan's party on Saturday.
Are you going to call your friend?
[k]I'm[/k] [k]going[/k] [k]to[/k] [k]run[/k] [k]to[/k] [k]work[/k] [k]today[/k].
Matilde [k]is[/k] going to [k]visit[/k] us when she travels to Italy.
are
visiting
Questions with "be+ going to"

To form questions with "going to", we use this structure: to be + (person/subject) + "going to" + verb. If we use a question word, it goes at the beginning: question word+ to be (person/subject)+ "going to" + verb. Here are some examples.
Is she going to have dinner with us?
Where is she going to move to?
What's the question form of the following statement?: Rose is going to run the London marathon.
Is Rose going to run the London marathon?
Does Rose run the London marathon?
Where does Rose run the London marathon?
To form negative sentences with "going to" we add "not" after the verb "to be", like this: to be + "not" + "going to" + verb. We can shorten the word "not" in a couple of different ways.
They're not going to have dinner with us. OR They aren't going to have dinner with us.
He is too lazy! He's not going to cycle home. OR He is too lazy! He isn't going to cycle home.
We'[k]re[/k] not going to meet this evening.
aren't
Complete the sentence so it is negative.
Sorry, I'm [k]not[/k] going to do the washing up again.
When do we use "be + going to"?
We use "be+ going to":
to talk about plans and intentions: I'm going to study 10 minutes a day.
when we can see that something is going to happen: The bus is late, we're not going to be on time.
Match each sentence with its use.
I'm going to move to the US.
Be careful! The food is going to burn.
we talk about a plan or an intention
we are certain something is going to happen

As you might have noticed "will" and "be + going to" are quite similar and in practise many people use them interchangeably. In the table below there's a summary of when we normally use each future form:
will
be + going to
to talk about a spontaneous decision: I will try the masala curry. It looks delicious!
to talk about a planned activity: I am going to have lunch with Ed later.
when we think or believe something about the future: I think my team will win.
when we know something is likely to happen: Yes, another goal! My team is going to win this game.
to make an offer, a promise or a threat: I'll clean the dishes after dinner.
to talk about intentions: I'm going to learn English and move to London!
"Will" or "be+ going to"?
Listen to the audio.
Which sentence describes a planned activity?
I'm going to go to the gym in the morning.
After that I'm free.
When will you finish at the gym?
Complete the sentence with the future form we use to talk about planned activities:
We'[k]re going to[/k] move to Barcelona next year.
Which sentence describes a spontaneous decision about the future?
I like this shirt a lot. I'll buy it!
I'm going to buy new clothes this afternoon.
I bought a shirt that I like.
Complete the sentence with the future form we use to talk about spontaneous decisions:

Waiter: "Today's special is bao buns." 
Customer: "Sounds good, I[k]'ll|will[/k] try one of those then."
Match the pairs of words / phrases.
will
be + going to
spontaneous decisions
plans
Which sentence is a promise?
I'll call you later.
Let's do something.
I'm going to go to the gym.
You don't need to worry about dinner, I'[k]ll|will[/k] cook tonight.
Complete the sentence with the future form we use with promises.
Rick says he [k]'s going to|is going to[/k] ask her number next time.
will
be + going to
to make promises
to talk about intentions
Lou is very smart, I think she[k]'ll|will[/k] get the job.
Complete the sentence with the future form we use when we know something is likely to happen.
It's so late! We[k]are going to|'re going to[/k] miss the plane!
Lou is very smart, I think she'll get the job.
It's so late! We're going to miss the plane.
we believe or think it'll happen
we predict this will happen based on current evidence
